pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:2.1: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:4.1: 5. The training rule on receiving food
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:5.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:5.2: At that time the nun Sundarīnandā was beautiful.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:5.3: When people saw her in the dining hall, they gave her the best food, both the donors and the recipient being lustful.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:5.4: The nun Sundarīnandā ate as much as she wanted,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:5.5: but other nuns did not get as much as they had intended.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:6.1: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:6.3: “How could Venerable Sundarīnandā, being lustful, eat either staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from the hands of a lustful man?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:6.4: “Is it true, monks, that Sundarīnandā did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:6.7: How can Sundarīnandā, being lustful, eat either staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from the hands of a lustful man?
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:6.8: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:6.9: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:7.1: ‘If a lustful nun eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from the hands of a lustful man, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:8.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Orders through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:9.2: having lust, longing for, in love with.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:10.2: having lust, longing for, in love with.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:11.2: a human male, not a male spirit, not a male ghost, not a male animal. He understands and is capable of having lust.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:12.2: apart from the five staple foods and water and toothwood—the rest is called “non-staple food.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:13.2: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:14.1: If she receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, she commits an serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:14.2: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:15.2: this is said with reference to the preceding offenses.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:16.2: there is an offense as soon as the misconduct is committed, and no pressing is required.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:17.2: she is sent away from the Order.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:18.2: … Therefore, too, it is called an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:19.1: If she receives water or toothwood, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:19.2: If only the man has lust, and she receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.1: For every mouthful, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.2: If she receives water or toothwood, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.3: If both of them have lust, and she receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it from the hand of a male spirit, a male ghost, a eunuch, or a male animal in human form, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.4: For every mouthful, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.5: If she receives water or toothwood, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.6: If only the male being has lust, and she receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.7: For every mouthful, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5:20.8: If she receives water or toothwood, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
